Scott Walker, best-known for creating innovative music, died of undisclosed causes on March 22, 2019, according to his record company. He was 76. A powerful pop singer in the 1960s and 1970s in The Walker Brothers, he later became an important force in experimental music hugely influencing artists like David Bowie. Dick Dale, surf rock icon, died on March 16, 2019, after suffering from various health issues for a long time. He was 81. Dale was best-known for his pioneering hit version of 1962's “Misirlou,” that was used as the theme for "Pulp Fiction" (1994). Released in 1963, Dale's instrumental “Let’s Go Trippin’” is known as the first surf rock song. His staccato playing style and use of Middle Eastern melodies was a giant influence on generations of musicians. Seen here, Dale performs at the Musicians Hall of Fame awards show at the Schermerhorn Symphony Center on Oct. 12, 2009, in Nashville, Tenn.  (Josh Anderson / AP)
